qas.question: Along with the Baltic and Spain, in what area were crusades called?
Where was the Teutonic Order headquartered in 1309?
What military order was founded as a result of the Northern Crusades?

answers.text: the Order of the Sword Brothers

qas.question: In what century did the Northern Crusades begin?
What century saw the end of the Northern Crusades?

context: Popes called for crusades to take place elsewhere besides the Holy Land: in Spain, <a0_0>southern France<a0_0/>, and along the Baltic. The Spanish crusades became fused with the Reconquista of Spain from the Muslims. Although the Templars and Hospitallers took part in the Spanish crusades, similar Spanish military religious orders were founded, most of which had become part of the two main orders of Calatrava and Santiago by the beginning of the 12th century. Northern Europe also remained outside Christian influence until the 11th century or later, and became a crusading venue as part of the Northern Crusades of the <a3_0>12th<a3_0/> to <a4_0>14th<a4_0/> centuries. These crusades also spawned a military order, <a2_0>the Order of the Sword Brothers<a2_0/>. Another order, the Teutonic Knights, although originally founded in the crusader states, focused much of its activity in the Baltic after 1225, and in 1309 moved its headquarters to <a1_0>Marienburg<a1_0/> in Prussia.
